event: diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma
treated by resection and radiotherapy
developed a stenosis of the esophagus
repeated aspiration led to several episodes of respiratory insufficiency due to pneumonia and purulent pleurisy
treated by pleurectomy
developed a restrictive ventilation pattern and a recurrent nerve palsy
treated by percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy and tracheostoma
put on home ventilation
mobility decreased
developed secondary depression
stopped talking
mandible was nearly fixed
could not open her mouth over a maximum of 20 degrees
left axis vertebralis was stented
developed stenosis of the internal axis carotis on both sides
diagnosed with arterial hypertension and secondary lactase deficiency
esophageal stenosis was dilated
referred to the University of Erlangen due to a decreasing general condition
fistula between the esophagus and tracheal membrane had occurred
examined by several chiefs and consultants
deemed too unstable for open surgery
inability to open the mouth and the recurrent nerve palsy
referred to our hospital on the surgical intensive care unit
suffering from pneumonia by 4-multiresistente gramnegative Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the right lung
put on veno-venous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (vv-ECMO)
thoracic computed tomography confirmed a big fistula of the tracheal membrane
decision to try endobronchial stenting was made
procedure was performed
vv-ECMO began to be partly ineffective due to rising septical issues
high volume input of physiological saline was needed
oral approach would only allow a small flexible bronchoscope
approach for the upper part of the trachea had to be performed through the percutaneous tracheostoma in a retrograde manner
trying different Dumon and one-hybrid self expandable metalic y-stent
plan was to changeover to a more floppy Freitag stent (FS)
successful retrograde stenting was performed in four steps
Step I: manually compressed “y” of the FS was successfully pushed downward on the main carina
Step II: frontal surface of the stent was cut with at least 1 cm opening in the longitudinal axis
Step III: jagwire was introduced through the mouth into the trachea
Step IV: regular tracheal cannula was introduced for ventilation
lungs were not aerated at that point of time
spontaneous breathing work increased and the vv-ECMO support was reduced
lungs became re-aerated again
patient woke up again and could communicate with her family by writing and her eyes
infections continued to be very severe
spontaneous work of breathing never exceeded a tidal ventilation of 170 mL per breath
reduction of intravenous saline injection was limited
patient along with her family decided actively to reduce the vv-ECMO support
patient died on 18 November 2016 due to pulmonary infection
